title: Joint multi-band deconvolution for Euclid and Vera C. Rubin images
author: U. Akhaury (Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne), P. Jablonka (Observatoire de Paris), F. Courbin (Universitat de Barcelona), J.-L. Starck (Université Paris-Saclay), ..., J. Starck (FORTH, Greece)
relevance_why: The paper discusses advanced deconvolution techniques that could inspire methodologies for audio signal processing, especially in enhancing resolution and feature recovery in audio signals.
background: This study focuses on improving the resolution of ground-based astronomical images by combining data from multiple bandwidth sources.
contribution: This paper introduces a multi-band deconvolution technique using high-resolution space observations to enhance ground-based images, achieving near Hubble Space Telescope quality.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods typically deconvolve images from a single band, limiting resolution improvement and noise handling.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work employs a joint deconvolution approach, integrating multiple bands’ information to optimize resolution and flux accuracy.

key_innovation: The method concurrently processes multiple photometric bands by leveraging correlations with high-resolution space-based data, significantly enhancing deconvolution results.
real_world_impact: The findings could improve the quality and accuracy of astronomical data processing, which is crucial for understanding cosmic structures, and may also provide insights applicable to audio signal restoration techniques.
limitations: No explicit limitations are mentioned by the authors.

new_terms.deconvolution: **Deconvolution** is a mathematical operation that reverses the effects of convolution on recorded data, often used to enhance image quality by removing blurring.
new_terms.Point Spread Function (PSF): **Point Spread Function (PSF)** describes how a point source of light is imaged by an optical system, essential for understanding blurring effects in imaging systems.

open_sourcing: The codes utilized in this article are publicly accessible on GitHub.
